Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Nanophosphors as Ultra-Sensitive Lateral Flow Reporters in a Lab-on-Phone Platform
Award.AbstractNarration:
Diagnostic uncertainty or delay can exact a substantial toll on morbidity and mortality, especially with infectious diseases. For several critical medical conditions, reliable diagnostic tests currently have turnaround times of hours to days, besides requiring expensive equipment and trained personnel. Point-of-care (POC) diagnostics enable better disease management and patient care through decentralization and rapid time-to-result, and are rapidly growing in usage. Of all the existing and potential POC technologies and formats, the Lateral Flow Test (LFT), a nearly three decades-old technology, most readily meets the usability criteria and is, therefore, preferred over other formats when it is applicable and has sufficient sensitivity. However, commercially available LFTs for several critical diseases lack the analytical sensitivity and the cost-effective quantitative ability required to make a large clinical impact. When specific and stable antibodies to an analyte are used in combination with an LFT strip composed of the right components, the analytical sensitivity of an LFT is determined by the detectability of the reporter particle. The LFT reporters that have been developed thus far, to overcome the limitations of the colorimetric labels have not had a large impact in the POC market, and are likely to remain limited in their adoption, due to a combination of cost and practicality.

The key innovation in the proposed technology is the use of 'nanophosphors', silica-encapsulated persistent luminescent nanoparticles, as Lateral Flow Test (LFT) reporters. Nanophosphors can enable the objective, ultrasensitive and quantitative measurement of analyte levels from complex samples through LFTs that use only a cell phone's built-in optics and an inexpensive plastic attachment for readout. The LFT is one of the most widely used point-of-care assay formats owing to its versatility and simplicity. LFTs have been hugely successful in applications including home pregnancy testing, but are not quantitative, and suffer from sensitivity and reproducibility limitations. Nanophosphors have an intense luminescence emission that lasts for several minutes after exposure to light available from inexpensive optical components like a cell phone flash. They are therefore more detectable than the currently used and visually-read colloidal gold, and when used as LFT reporters, allow the quantitative detection of much lower analyte concentrations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent changes in healthcare and an increasing role of technology in society have spurred demand for highly sensitive point-of-care diagnostics for both medical professionals in the clinic and consumers in home-testing applications. Despite extensive research and development during the last few decades, many point-of-care testing methods such as the lateral flow assay (LFA) still suffer from poor sensitivity. Light-emitting reporters such as fluorescent nanoparticles can be incorporated into LFAs and other point-of-care testing formats to improve sensitivity, but with the tradeoff of requiring readout instrumentation and optical hardware that is often too cumbersome, expensive, and impractical for many end users.  Persistent luminescence, also called long-lifetime phosphorescence, is a phenomenon wherein an inorganic material emits visible luminescence for minutes to hours after photoexcitation. We hypothesized that “nanophosphors” derived from such materials could be used as highly sensitive reporters in assays when analyzed via a simple time-resolved photoluminescence detection strategy which eliminates the need for the expensive optical hardware essential for sensitive fluorescence readout. In previous work we demonstrated that nanophosphors could be applied in LFAs to achieve better analytical sensitivity than gold nanoparticles. Expanding on this work, we have developed a smartphone-based point-of-care platform that enables highly sensitive and quantitative photoluminescence imaging of nanophosphor LFA strips by using a phone’s camera and flash with a simple, inexpensive phone attachment. Additionally, we are exploring strategies to synthesize nanophosphors from the bottom-up with properties tailored to improve their performance in diagnostic assays.

   Our I-Corps team underwent the full, rigorous training at the USC site, and did customer discovery in the Los Angeles area and then back in Houston.    We confirmed market demand for our product, but learned a great deal about the structure of the market, and modified our understanding of our value proposition.

   We also have continued to develop our prototype, and Luminostics is successfully launched.  We've received follow-on funding from the NIH and CDC, and are moving forward.
